stories.title: Behind the scenes: Redpanda Cloud's response to the GCP outage
stories.author: eatonphil
stories.article_summary: On June 12, 2025, a global outage of Google Cloud Platform (GCP) due to an automated API quota update significantly impacted many services, but Redpanda Cloud maintained stability for its customers. Redpanda's cell-based architecture, which co-locates critical services and enforces a minimum replication factor of 3, allowed it to uphold a 99.99% availability SLA, with some clusters even achieving 99.999%. During the outage, Redpanda's proactive response included monitoring metrics independently and reaching out to customers experiencing tiered storage errors, demonstrating their commitment to reliable service. "The whole is greater than the sum of its parts," they noted, emphasizing the importance of robust safety and reliability measures in complex systems.

comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: Analysis failed due to JSON parsing error
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: RedPanda remained unaffected during a major internet outage because they didn't rely on the GCP services that failed and maintained their own monitoring, despite their third-party alerting system going down. The commenter expected a more dramatic account of RedPanda's response or innovative failover technology.

top_comments.author: RadiozRadioz
top_comments.text:
Hmm. Here's what I read from this article: RedPanda didn't happen to use any of the stuff in GCP that went down, so they were unaffected. They use a 3rd party for alerting and dashboarding, and that 3rd party went down, but RedPanda still had their own monitoring.
When I read "major outage for a large part of the internet was just another normal day for Redpanda Cloud customers", I expected a brave tale of RedPanda SREs valiantly fixing things, or some cool automatic failover tech. What I got instead was: Google told RedPanda there was an issue, RedPanda had a look and their service was unaffected, nothing needed failing over, then someone at RedPanda wrote an article bragging about their triple-nine uptime & fault tolerance.
I get it, an SRE is doing well if you don't notice them, but the only real preventative measure I saw here that directly helped with this issue, is that they over provision disk space. Which I'd be alarmed if they didn't do.

top_comments.author: literallyroy
top_comments.text: Yeah I thought they were going to show something cool like multi-tenant architecture. Odd to write this article when it was clear they expected to be impacted as they were reaching out to customers.

top_comments.author: dangoodmanUT
top_comments.text: I think you're missing the point. What I took away was that: "Because we design for zero dependencies for full operation, we didn't go down". Their extra features like tiered storage and monitoring going down didn't affect normal operations, which it seems like it did for similar solutions with similar features.

top_comments.author: rybosome
top_comments.text: Must be hell inside GCP right now. That was a big outage, and they were tired of big outages years ago. It was already extremely difficult to move quickly and get things done due to the reliability red tape, and I have to imagine this will make it even harder.

top_comments.author: siscia
top_comments.text:
In fairness, their design does not seem to be regional. With problems in one region bringing down another, apparently not unrelated, region.
With this kind of architecture, this sort of problems is just bound to happen.
During my time in AWS, region independence was a must. And some services were able to operate at least for a while without degrading also when some core dependencies were not available. Think like loosing S3.
And after that, the service would keep operating, but with a degraded experience.
I am stunned that this level of isolation is not common in GCP.

top_comments.author: rybosome
top_comments.text:
Global dependencies were disallowed back in 2018 with a tiny handful of exceptions that were difficult or impossible to make fully regional. Chemist, the service that went down, was one of those.
Generally GCP wants regionality, but because it offers so many higher-level inter-region features, some kind of a global layer is basically inevitable.

top_comments.author: dangoodmanUT
top_comments.text: Does Route53 depend on services in us-east-1 though? Or maybe it's something else, but i recall us-east-1 downtime causing service downtime for global services

top_comments.author: valenterry
top_comments.text: How does AWS do that though? Do the re-implement all the code in every region? Because even the slightest re-use of code could trigger a synchronous (possibly delayed) downtime of all regions.

top_comments.author: crop_rotation
top_comments.text:
Reusing code doesn't trigger region dependencies.
> Do the re-implement all the code in every region?
Everyone does.
The difference is AWS very strongly ensures that regions are independent failure domains. The GCP architecture is global with all the pros and cons that implies. e.g GCP has a truly global load balancer while AWS can not since everything is at core regional.

top_comments.author: buremba
top_comments.text: I think making the identity piece regional hurts the UX a lot. I like GCP's approach, where you manage multiple regions with a single identity, but I'm not sure how they can make it resilient to regional failures.

stories.title: Scaling our observability platform by embracing wide events and replacing OTel
stories.author: valyala
stories.article_summary: The article discusses the evolution of LogHouse, a logging platform that expanded from 19 PiB to over 100 PB of uncompressed data, handling a surge from ~40 trillion to 500 trillion rows. Key insights include a dramatic 20× increase in event volume managed with less than 10% of the CPU previously required, achieved by developing a custom pipeline that addressed inefficiencies in OpenTelemetry (OTel), which was unable to scale effectively. The introduction of HyperDX, a ClickHouse-native observability UI, allowed for enhanced exploration and root-cause analysis, transitioning from a Grafana-based UI to a more integrated ClickStack observability stack. The article emphasizes the importance of specialized tools for high-throughput scenarios, noting that "the real gold lies in its system tables," which capture crucial operational insights beyond standard output.

agreement_points: There is a consensus that excessive logging can obscure important correlations in data, which can lead to missed insights and prolonged debugging processes.
disagreement_points: The debate over whether to log everything or filter logs highlights differing philosophies on data management, with some advocating for comprehensive logging to aid in debugging while others warn of the costs and complexities involved.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects a nuanced understanding of logging practices, with participants highlighting the challenges of managing large volumes of log data. There is a clear divide between those advocating for comprehensive logging to aid in debugging and those warning of the costs and inefficiencies associated with excessive data retention. The community recognizes the importance of balancing log management with performance needs, emphasizing the need for effective strategies to optimize logging practices.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter argues that storing excessive logs (100PB) indicates a failure to identify valuable data, suggesting that metrics and structured events can capture most insights. They propose implementing auto-pruning for unused logs to avoid creating a "digital landfill."

specific_numbers: 100PB of logs mentioned indicates a significant amount of data being stored, suggesting inefficiencies in logging practices that could lead to wasted resources and difficulty in identifying valuable information.
The decay of log value post-bug closure highlights the need for effective log management, as retaining unnecessary logs can clutter systems and hinder performance.
tools_mentioned: Observability platforms are discussed as essential for managing logs, emphasizing their role in filtering and analyzing data to derive actionable insights.
Java's logging performance issues illustrate the importance of choosing the right programming language and logging framework to optimize application speed and resource usage.
performance_data: The mention of applications becoming noticeably faster by clearing out irrelevant logs underscores the impact of log management on overall application performance, which can lead to better user experiences.

price_comparisons: The costs associated with logging everything can divert funds from other critical areas, suggesting a need for a balanced approach to logging that maximizes value while minimizing expenses.
resource_requirements: The need for efficient log filtering systems highlights the resource demands of managing large volumes of logs, which can strain infrastructure if not properly managed.
efficiency_gains: Implementing auto-pruning of logs can lead to significant efficiency improvements by reducing storage costs and improving system performance, allowing teams to focus on more critical tasks.

setup_instructions: Setting up auto-pruning for logs is essential to maintain system performance and prevent unnecessary data accumulation, which can lead to slower query responses.
configuration_details: Configuring log levels appropriately can optimize performance and reduce noise in log data, ensuring that only relevant information is captured for analysis.

strong_agreements: There is a consensus that excessive logging can obscure important correlations in data, which can lead to missed insights and prolonged debugging processes.
major_disagreements: The debate over whether to log everything or filter logs highlights differing philosophies on data management, with some advocating for comprehensive logging to aid in debugging while others warn of the costs and complexities involved.
expert_opinions: Experts emphasize the importance of balancing log retention with performance needs, as retaining too much data can lead to inefficiencies and complicate troubleshooting efforts.

market_trends: The trend towards more sophisticated log management tools indicates a growing recognition of the importance of observability in software development, which can enhance operational efficiency and reduce downtime.
company_strategies: Companies are increasingly adopting practices like log auto-pruning to streamline operations and reduce costs, positioning themselves to respond more effectively to incidents.

working_setups: Successful implementations of observability platforms that include auto-pruning features have resulted in improved system performance and reduced operational costs.

actionable_advice: Implement log retention policies that prioritize valuable data to enhance performance and reduce costs, ensuring that only necessary logs are kept.
what_to_avoid: Avoid logging everything indiscriminately, as this can lead to data overload and make it difficult to identify critical issues when they arise.
optimization_tips: Regularly review and clean up logs to maintain system efficiency and prevent performance degradation, which can save time during debugging.

top_comments.author: b0a04gl
top_comments.text: tbh that's not the flex. storing 100PB of logs just means we haven't figured out what's actually worth logging. metrics + structured events can usually tell 90% of the story. the rest? trace level chaos no one reads unless prod's on fire. what'd could've done better be: auto pruning logs that no alert ever looked at. or logs that never hit a search query in 3 months. call it attention weighted retention. until then this is just high end digital landfill with compression

top_comments.author: hinkley
top_comments.text:
That logging isn’t even free on the sending side, especially in languages where they are eager to get the logs to disk in case the final message reveals why the program crashed.
And there’s a lot of scanning blindness out there. Too much extraneous data can hide correlations between other logs entries. And there’s half life in value of logs written for bugs that are already closed, and it’s fairly short.
I prefer stats because of the way they get aggregated. Though for GIL languages some models like OTEL have higher overhead than they should.

top_comments.author: hnlmorg
top_comments.text:
I’m of the opposite opinion. It’s better to ingest everything and then filter out the stuff you don’t want at the observability platform.
The problem of filtering out debug logs is you don’t need them, until you do. And then trying to recreate an event you can’t even debug is often impossible. So it’s easier to then retrieve those debug logs if they’re already there but hidden.

top_comments.author: hinkley
top_comments.text: Once a bug is closed the value of those logs starts to decay. And the fact is that we get punished for working on things that aren’t in the sprint, and working on “done done” stories is one of those ways. Even if you want to clean up your mess, there’s incentive not to. And many of us very clearly don’t like to clean up our own messes, so a ready excuse gets them out of the conversation about a task they don’t want to be voluntold to do.

top_comments.author: jgalt212
top_comments.text:
> then filter out the stuff you don’t want
This is often easier said than done. And there's ginormous costs associated with logging everything. Money that can be better spent elsewhere.
Also, logging everything creates yet another security hole to worry about.

top_comments.author: hinkley
top_comments.text: Java had particularly bad performance for logging for a good while and I used to make applications noticeably faster by clearing out the logs nobody cared about anymore. Just have to be careful about side effects in the log lines.

top_comments.author: phillipcarter
top_comments.text:
> And there's ginormous costs associated with logging everything
If you use a tool that defaults the log spew to a cheap archive, sampling to the fast store, and a way to pull from the archive on-demand much of that is resolved. FWIW I think most orgs get big scared at seeing $$$ in their cloud bills, but don't properly account for time spent by engineers rummaging around for data they need but don't have.

top_comments.author: hnlmorg
top_comments.text:
Not really. Most observability platforms already have tools to support this kind of workflow in a more cost effective way.
> Also, logging everything creates yet another security hole to worry about.
I think the real problem isn’t logging, it’s the fact that your developers are logging sensitive information. If they’re doing that, then it’s a moot point if those logs are also being pushed to a third party observability platform or not because you’re already leaking sensitive information.

top_comments.author: gavinray
top_comments.text: "Better to have it and not need it; than to need it, and not have it..."

top_comments.author: jkogara
top_comments.text: Or more succinctly, albeit less eloquently: "Better to be looking at it than looking for it."

stories.title: Using Microsoft's New CLI Text Editor on Ubuntu
stories.author: jandeboevrie
stories.article_summary: Microsoft has introduced Edit, an open-source command-line text editor built in Rust, designed primarily for Windows but also compatible with Linux and macOS. With a lightweight footprint of just 250kB, Edit features a user-friendly text-driven UI, modeless operation, and essential functionalities like Find and Replace (supporting regex), word wrap, and file encoding options. It aims to provide a familiar experience for VS Code users by sharing keybindings, making it easier for them to transition from traditional editors like Vim or Nano. While lacking advanced features like syntax highlighting, Edit is positioned for speed and simplicity, with future enhancements planned. To install it on Ubuntu, users can download the binary from GitHub or use the unofficial snap package with the command `sudo snap install msedit`.

agreement_points: There is a consensus that the terms TUI and CLI are often conflated, which can lead to misunderstandings about the capabilities and use cases of different text editors.
disagreement_points: The debate on whether ed qualifies as a CLI or TUI reveals differing opinions on the definitions of these interfaces, indicating a lack of clarity that can affect user expectations and software design.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects a nuanced understanding of text editing interfaces, with participants emphasizing the importance of clear definitions and historical context. The conflation of CLI and TUI terms is a recurring theme, suggesting that clarity in terminology is crucial for effective communication and user experience in software development.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter critiques the article for blending distinct concepts and lacking historical context, particularly highlighting the differences between TUI and CLI. They also note that the new editor is a reimplementation of the classic MS-DOS 5 EDIT program, predating the popularity of VIM.

tools_mentioned: MS-DOS 5 ED is being discussed as a reimplementation of classic text editors, highlighting the historical context of text editing tools and their evolution in user interfaces.

compatibility_issues: The discussion around the differences between CLI and TUI highlights potential compatibility issues when transitioning between text editors, as users may expect different functionalities and behaviors.

strong_agreements: There is a consensus that the terms TUI and CLI are often conflated, which can lead to misunderstandings about the capabilities and use cases of different text editors.
major_disagreements: The debate on whether ed qualifies as a CLI or TUI reveals differing opinions on the definitions of these interfaces, indicating a lack of clarity that can affect user expectations and software design.

top_comments.author: felineflock
top_comments.text:
I appreciate the effort that went into writing the article but it conflates different concepts missing some historical context and technical distinctions.
For example, TUI (text user interface) and CLI (command-line interface) are quite different. "CLI Text Editor" sounds more like someone editing a file using ECHO commands.
This new editor is actually a reimplementation of the classic MS-DOS 5 EDIT program from 1991. At that time, VIM was still very new, so "VIM memes" weren't yet part of the tech landscape.
Before VIM, there was vi. In Usenet posts - about 15 years before Google - people used to add a pithy humorous sentence at the bottom called "tagline" - here is one: "How do you exit vi? Reboot the system."
And Notepad was not the only option for Windows devs. We've had EDIT, DR-DOS EDITOR, Brief, WordPad, EditPad, Notepad++, and more.

top_comments.author: abhgh
top_comments.text:
I noticed the conflation of terms too but it seems to arise out of the original Microsoft announcement!
https://devblogs.microsoft.com/commandline/edit-is-now-open-...

top_comments.author: bee_rider
top_comments.text:
Does the exclamation point work in vi, like vim? So the way to exit is to do:
:!killall vi
Of course.
For a cli text editor, ed would qualify, right?

top_comments.author: rbanffy
top_comments.text: MS-DOS had edlin, which was their own take on ed. They never made a firm commitment, however, to make edlin the standard editor.

top_comments.author: diggan
top_comments.text:
> For a cli text editor, ed would qualify, right?
It'd still say ed is more of a TUI than CLI, albeit kind of old-school since it doesn't redraw the screen, just continuously show output and let you enter commands. Maybe "REPL" comes closer, because it's not interactive in the typical TUI way.

top_comments.author: layer8
top_comments.text: I fail to see the difference between REPL and CLI here. Any line-based interactive interface where you type commands is a CLI, like for example the ftp or mysql clients in interactive mode. Or, indeed, ed.

top_comments.author: kristjansson
top_comments.text: Could you run it on an actual teletype without consuming an entire forest worth of paper? That’s a CLI. Otherwise it’s a TUI.

top_comments.author: MobiusHorizons
top_comments.text: Personally I usually make the distinction based on whether the process has to switch the tty to raw mode and overwrites the full screen (typically using ncurses), but it sounds like the person you are replying to makes the distinction in whether the program needs user input while executing. I guess such programs are more likely to work in pipelines or shell scripts

top_comments.author: layer8
top_comments.text: Unix shells “need user input while executing” in that sense. A program not being a Unix shell doesn’t make it non-CLI.

top_comments.author: hamburglar
top_comments.text: Is it actually important that we come up with a formal definition of these things, though? They are colloquial terms, there is some overlap, and people are always going to use one or the other “incorrectly” according to you. It’s more important that we recognize that’s a potential source of differing terminology and ignore that rather than fixating on it.

stories.title: Samsung embeds IronSource spyware app on phones across WANA
stories.author: the-anarchist
stories.article_summary: Recent reports highlight concerns over the pre-installed bloatware AppCloud on Samsung's A and M series smartphones in West Asia and North Africa (WANA), developed by ironSource (acquired by Unity). This software, which collects sensitive data such as biometric information and IP addresses without user consent, is embedded deeply within the operating system, making it nearly impossible to uninstall without rooting the device—an action that voids warranties. The lack of transparency regarding AppCloud's privacy practices violates GDPR and local data protection laws, prompting an open letter to Samsung demanding clear disclosure of data handling, an effective opt-out mechanism, and a reconsideration of future pre-installations. The letter emphasizes that "users deserve to know what is installed on their devices and how their data is being used," especially in light of regional privacy rights.

agreement_points: There is a consensus that mass surveillance has serious implications for personal privacy and security, as highlighted by the connection drawn between surveillance and targeted attacks, indicating a growing concern about the misuse of data.
disagreement_points: There is debate over the effectiveness of current counter-drone technologies, with some arguing that they are outdated and ineffective against new drone technologies, which suggests a need for continuous innovation in defense strategies.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects a growing concern over the implications of mass surveillance and its potential to facilitate targeted violence, particularly in the context of drone technology. Commenters express skepticism about the effectiveness of current counter-drone measures, indicating a need for more advanced solutions. The mention of small explosive payloads raises alarms about the accessibility of lethal technology, emphasizing the urgency for regulatory and defensive measures in both civilian and military contexts.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter argues that actions by corporations that compromise security should be classified as criminal hacking or acts of war, highlighting the severity and implications of such behavior.

specific_numbers: 30 milligrams of high explosive is mentioned as sufficient to cause lethal harm, emphasizing the potential danger of small payloads in drone warfare and the implications for civilian safety and military tactics.
tools_mentioned: Counter-UAS tech is discussed, highlighting the ongoing development in drone defense systems, but it is noted that these technologies are often outdated quickly, which raises concerns about their effectiveness against evolving threats.

strong_agreements: There is a consensus that mass surveillance has serious implications for personal privacy and security, as highlighted by the connection drawn between surveillance and targeted attacks, indicating a growing concern about the misuse of data.
major_disagreements: There is debate over the effectiveness of current counter-drone technologies, with some arguing that they are outdated and ineffective against new drone technologies, which suggests a need for continuous innovation in defense strategies.

top_comments.author: like_any_other
top_comments.text: It's time to start treating such actions, including/especially when done by corporations, as criminal hacking or an act of war, because as many commenters noted, that is what it amounts to.

top_comments.author: boramalper
top_comments.text:
I suspect a strong link between mass surveillance (by corporations for advertising or by states for intelligence purposes) and the very recent targeting of the senior Iranian nuclear scientist and military officers at their homes in Iran.
Wherever you are from or whatever side of the conflict you are on, I think we can all agree that it’s never been easier to infer so much about a person from “semi-public” sources such as companies selling customer data and built-in apps that spy on their users and call home. It allows intelligence agencies to outsource intelligence gathering to the market, which is probably cheaper and a lot more convenient than traditional methods.
“Privacy is a human right” landed on deaf ears but hopefully politicians will soon realise that it’s a matter of national security too.

top_comments.author: kragen
top_comments.text:
The truth is far outside the Overton window.
Yes, privacy is a question of civil defense in the drone age. But the existing crop of states will never acknowledge that; their structure and institutions presume precisely the kind of mass databases of PII that create this vulnerability, as well as institutional transparency for public accountability. This makes them structurally vulnerable to insurgencies that expropriate those databases for targeting. The existing states will continue to clutch at their fantasies of adequately secured taxpayer databases until their territorial control (itself an anachronism in the drone age; boots on the ground can no longer provide security against things like Operation Spiderweb) has been reduced to a few fortified clandestine facilities.
Things are going to be very unpredictable and, I suspect, extremely violent.

top_comments.author: drewbug
top_comments.text: I used to feel this way until I learned about counter-UAS tech.

top_comments.author: kragen
top_comments.text:
That's wishful thinking. Flying drones aren't the only threat, or the main threat, and there isn't such a thing as "counter-UAS tech", only counter-yesterday's-UAS tech. Radio jamming was "counter-UAS tech" until the mass production of fiber-optic-controlled FPV drones starting five months ago, for example. You can still find vendors marketing it as such.
30 milligrams of high explosive is enough to open your daughter's skull, or, more relevantly, your commanding officer's daughter's skull, and there are a thousand ways to deliver it to her if she can be tracked: in pager batteries, crawling, swimming, floating, waiting for ambush, hitchhiking on migratory birds, hitchhiking on car undercarriages, in her Amazon Prime deliveries, falling from a hydrogen balloon in the mesosphere, and so on. And if 30mg is too much, 2mg of ricin on a mechanical ovipositor will do just as well.
All of this is technically possible today without any new discoveries. At this point it's a straightforward systems development exercise. And you can be sure that there are bad people working for multiple different countries' spy agencies who know this; they don't need me to tell them.

top_comments.author: bostik
top_comments.text:
> 30 milligrams of high explosive is enough to open your daughter's skull, or, more relevantly, your commanding officer's daughter's skull, and there are a thousand ways to deliver it
While we are talking about flying drones, we are not far off from Slaughterbots becoming reality.[0] Why bother with surgical assassinations if you can blanket entire regions with with swarms of autonomous seek-and-destroy explosives?
After all, as last two years have so amply demonstrated: people are fine with genocide.
0: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O-2tpwW0kmU

top_comments.author: kragen
top_comments.text:
Slaughterbots is just the beginning; it's definitely too late to prevent that scenario now.
Why bother? For the same reason to bother with surgical assassinations if you can blanket entire regions with nuclear fireballs. Radioactive wastelands are unprofitable! This is a general problem with genocide: it only gets you land, and since the Green Revolution land is abundant. Protection rackets, on the otehr hand, are highly profitable, but only with some exclusivity; if extortionists multiply, the unique Nash equilibrium is multiple gangs that collectively demand many times the victims' total revenues, resulting in ecological collapse.
More generally, the threat of violence is only effective as a form of coercion when you can credibly withdraw the violence as a reward for compliance. Violence provides no incentive to comply to someone who believes they are just as likely to be a victim whether they comply or not.
But swarms of autonomous seek-and-destroy explosives are plausibly the most effective way to provide that surgical-assassination threat, perhaps combined with poisons, solid penetrators, and/or incendiaries. The Minority Report spiders (not yet technically feasible) or a quadcopter can be enormously more selective than a GBU-57, a Hellfire missile, or even a hand grenade, and can choose to avert their attack at the last millisecond upon the presentation of properly signed do-not-assassinate orders, even if long-distance communication is jammed.

stories.article_summary: The "Art of Bijective Combinatorics" (ABjC) is a unique educational resource created by Xavier Viennot, consisting of 77 video lectures recorded at the Institute of Mathematical Sciences (IMSc) in Chennai, India, from 2016 to 2019. This "video-book" includes four parts covering topics such as enumerative combinatorics and orthogonal polynomials, with courses designed for both undergraduate and graduate students, as well as researchers. The website allows users to navigate the videos interactively, linking directly to specific lecture points, thus overcoming common video limitations. As Viennot states, "the emphasis of the course being on the bijective point of view in combinatorics," the resource combines visual mathematics with modern technology, making it a valuable tool for those in mathematics, physics, and computer science. For citation, one can reference the parts similarly to books, e.g., "The Art of Bijective Combinatorics, Part II, IMSc

stories.title: Fundamental Problems of Lisp, the Cons Cell (2024)
stories.author: gudzpoz
stories.article_summary: In "Fundamental Problems of LISP, the Cons Cell," Xah Lee critiques the core data structure of Lisp—the cons cell—arguing that it limits list construction to a maximum of two elements, necessitating complex nesting for longer lists. He states, "Lisp's cons is perhaps the greatest fuck up in the history of computer languages," highlighting its historical entrenchment in Lisp for over four decades and the resulting complications in list processing. Lee suggests actionable improvements, such as establishing standards for "proper lists" and marking cons-related constructs as obsolete, drawing on examples from languages like Racket and Clojure, which have addressed these limitations. He emphasizes that while simple list usage is common, the cumbersome nature of cons becomes problematic in more complex applications, particularly as programming paradigms evolve.

The conversation reflects a mix of respect for Lisp's foundational role in programming and frustration over its perceived limitations in comparison to contemporary languages.

top_comments.author: noosphr
top_comments.text:
>Lisp at core is based on functional programing on lists.
Lisp is not, nor has it ever been, a functional programming language. It had lambda decades before other languages figured out it was a good idea, but it had set! for just as long.
It is also not a list based language, but a tree based one. The fundamental point of lisps is that you can manipulate the abstract syntax tree directly since it's pretty much the same thing as the parse tree.
>Deep Nesting is Rare
>The lisp's cons [...] works just fine when data structure used is simple. [...] vast majority of list usage is just simple flat list, sometimes 2 level of nesting [...] 3 levels of nesting is seldom used [...] Greater than 3 level is rarely seen. Systematic manipulation and exploitation of nested list, such as mapping to leafs, to particular level, transposition by permutation on level, or list structure pattern matching in today's functional langs, etc is hardly ever to be seen.
I guess the author has never used lisp to implement a DSL in lisp. Writing a lisp interpreted in lisp is the first real program you write if you take a lisp course at university and you need to handle arbitrarily nested expressions.
Real world usage also involves writing a specialist language to solve your problem for anything more complex than a utility script, e.g. Emacs is a text editing DSL implemented in elisp.

top_comments.text: I'm not sure but I kinda recall some old lisper saying they added imperative features due to idioms outside of the lisp lab. `progn` was a way to appeal to fortran coders, i believe `set!` was in the same bag..

top_comments.author: Jtsummers
top_comments.text: set! is from Scheme. Lisp has had set and setq since the beginning along with prog (I don't know when progn was added).

top_comments.author: golly_ned
top_comments.text: The author is reknowned for eMacs lisp.

top_comments.author: noosphr
top_comments.text: The author is renowned for flame wars on comp.lang.lisp which boil down to "Hey guys, why isn't lisp mathematica?".

top_comments.author: rurban
top_comments.text: The author is used be in the killfile, so you don't have endure his endless wrongs

top_comments.author: DonaldFisk
top_comments.text:
The cons is integral to Lisp, and is used to construct the list, which is a purely functional data structure. Other languages also have lists, e.g. Prolog and Haskell (as well as similar pure functional languages).
Saying that they're a fundamental problem in Lisp is like saying that objects are a fundamental problem in Smalltalk or that arrays are a fundamental problem in APL.
If Xah doesn't like cons cells, there are other languages he can use instead. Lisp (as well as Prolog, Haskell, ML, etc.) programmers won't be persuaded to abandon cons cells or lists as they find them extremely useful.

top_comments.author: dwringer
top_comments.text: Also to be fair to Common Lisp, it has lots of support for sequences that aren't functional lists. Cons cells just happen to be convenient for representing things like the source code so they are prevalent. They're hardly a requirement for any algorithm's logical implementation.

top_comments.author: lelanthran
top_comments.text:
> Lisp (as well as Prolog, Haskell, ML, etc.) programmers won't be persuaded to abandon cons cells or lists as they find them extremely useful.
Who said anything about abandoning lists? The argument appears to be that lists don't need to be built up out of two-element cells (i.e cons cells), and that Lisp, by enforcing `cons` cells as a way to construct lists, is seeing some limitations.
TBH, I agree a little that that PoV - there is no need for exposing the implementation of the list to the programmer, much less forcing the programmer into using the implementation.
The other problem with enforcing lists to be constructed of cons cells is one of performance; the default list in Lisp is a cache-invalidating monster.

top_comments.author: astine
top_comments.text: Xah's complaint appears to be that cons cells are too low level a construct to expose to the user. He seems fine with lists in general but just dislikes how they are implemented in Lisp. If I were to implement a list in a non-Lisp language (like C or whatever,) it would likely internally include a struct called "Node" that filled the same purpose as cons cells do in Lisp. However, users of this hypothetical 'list' usually wouldn't directly interact with these "Nodes"; they would mostly be an implementation detail, as appears to be the case for most list implementations other than Lisp's. I think that Xah is wishing that was the case for Lisp as well.

stories.title: Phoenix.new – Remote AI Runtime for Phoenix
stories.author: wut42
stories.article_summary: Chris McCord, the creator of Elixir's Phoenix framework, has unveiled Phoenix.new, a fully-online coding agent designed to streamline the development of collaborative, real-time applications. Built on Fly.io, Phoenix.new operates in an ephemeral virtual machine, providing root shell access that allows agents to install packages and run programs without affecting the local environment. It features a headless Chrome browser for real-time interaction with applications, enabling the agent to autonomously build full-stack applications, including those using WebSockets and databases. McCord emphasizes that Phoenix.new can significantly reduce deployment times, citing Andrej Karpathy's week-long struggle to launch an app, which Phoenix.new aims to minimize. The tool supports integration with GitHub and is poised to shift developer workflows towards more automated, agent-driven processes.

top_comments.author: tiffanyh
top_comments.text:
Amazing work.
Just a clarifying question since I'm confused by the branding use of "Phoenix.new" (since I associate "Phoenix" as a web framework for Elixir apps but this seems to be a lot more than that).
- Is "Phoenix.new" an IDE?
- Is "Phoenix.new" ... AI to help you create an app using the Phoenix web framework for Elixir?
- Does "Phoenix.new" require the app to be hosted/deployed on Fly.io? If that's the case, maybe a naming like "phoenix.flyio.new" would be better and extensible for any type of service Fly.io helps in deployment - Phoenix/Elixir being one)
- Is it all 3 above?
And how does this compare to Tidewave.ai (created as presumably you know, by Elixir creator)
Apologies if I'm possibility conflating topics here.

top_comments.author: chrismccord
top_comments.text:
Yes all 3. It has been weird trying to position/brand this as we started out just going for full-stack Elixir/Phoenix and it became very clear this is already much bigger than a single stack. That said, we wanted to nail a single stack super well to start and the agent is tailored for vibe'd apps atm. I want to introduce a pair mode next for more leveled assistance without having to nag it.
You could absolutely treat phoenix.new as your full dev IDE environment, but I think about it less an IDE, and more a remote runtime where agents get work done that you pop into as needed. Or another way to think about it, the agent doesn't care or need the vscode IDE or xterm. They are purely conveniences for us meaty humans.
For me, something like this is the future of programming. Agents fiddling away and we pop in to see what's going on or work on things they aren't well suited for.
Tidewave is focused on improving your local dev experience while we sit on the infra/remote agent/codex/devin/jules side of the fence. Tidewave also has a MCP server which Phoenix.new could integrate with that runs inside your app itself.

top_comments.author: tills13
top_comments.text:
> For me, something like this is the future of programming. Agents fiddling away and we pop in to see what's going on or work on things they aren't well suited for.
Honestly, this is depressing. Pop in from what? Our factory jobs?

top_comments.author: brainless
top_comments.text: I understand that we are slowly taking away our own jobs but I do not find it depressing. I do find it concerning since most people do not talk about this openly. We are not sure how we are restructure so many jobs. If we cannot find jobs, what is the financial future for a large number of people across the world. This needs more thinking, honest acceptance of the situation. It will happen, we should take a positive approach to finding a new future.

top_comments.author: seanhandley
top_comments.text: Read up on the Jevons Paradox

top_comments.author: freedomben
top_comments.text:
> In economics, the Jevons paradox (/ˈdʒɛvənz/; sometimes Jevons effect) occurs when technological advancements make a resource more efficient to use (thereby reducing the amount needed for a single application); however, as the cost of using the resource drops, if the price is highly elastic, this results in overall demand increasing, causing total resource consumption to rise. Governments have typically expected efficiency gains to lower resource consumption, rather than anticipating possible increases due to the Jevons paradox.[1]
I do think there will be some Jevons effect going on with this, but I think it's important to recognize that software development as a resource is different than something like coal. For example, if the average iPhone-only teenager can now suddenly start cranking out apps, that may ultimately increase demand for apps and there may be more code than ever getting "written," but there won't necesarily be a need for your CS-grad software engineer anymore, so we could still be fucked. Why would you pay a high salary for a SWE when your business teams can just generate whatever app they need without having to know anything about how it actually works?
I think the arguments about "AI isn't good enough to replace senior engineers" will hold true for a few years, but not much beyond that. Jevon's Paradox will probably hold true for software as a resource, but not for SWEs as a resource. In the coal scenario, imagine that coal gets super cheap to procure because we invent robots that can do it from alpha to omega. Coal demand may go up, but the job for the coal miner is toast, and unless that coal miner has ownership stake, they will be out on their ass.
[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jevons_paradox

top_comments.author: mxkopy
top_comments.text:
The coal miner would have to pivot to being someone who knows a lot about coal instead of someone that actually obtained it, they’d become more of a coal-advisor to the person making decisions about what type of or how much coal to get/what’s even possible with the coal they’re getting.
The future I’m seeing with AI is one where software (i.e. as a way to get hardware to do stuff) is basically a non-issue. The example I wanna work on soon is telling Siri I want my iPhone to work as a touchpad for my computer and have the necessary drivers for that to happen be built automatically because that’s a reasonable thing I could expect my hardware to do. That’s the sort of thing that seems pretty achievable by AI in a couple turns that would take a single dev a year or two. And the thing is, I can’t imagine a software dev that doesn’t have some set of skills that are still applicable in this future, either through general CS skills (knowing what’s within reasonable expectations of hardware, being able to effectively describe more specific behavior/choosing the right abstractions etc) or other more nebulous technical knowledge (e.g. what you want to do with hardware in the first place).
Another thing I will mention is that for things like the iPhone example from earlier, there are usually a lot of optimizations or decisions involved that are derived from the user’s experience as a human which the LLM can’t really use synthetically. As another example if I turned my phone into a second monitor the LLM might generate code that sends full resolution images to the phone when the phone’s screen is much lower, there’s no real point for it to optimize that away if it doesn’t know how eyes work and what screens are used for. So at some point it needs to involve a model of a human, at least for examples like these.

top_comments.author: freedomben
top_comments.text:
> The coal miner would have to pivot to being someone who knows a lot about coal instead of someone that actually obtained it, they’d become more of a coal-advisor to the person making decisions about what type of or how much coal to get/what’s even possible with the coal they’re getting.
I definitely agree that there will be some jobs/roles like that, and it won't be 100% destruction of SWEs (and many other gigs that will be affected), but I can't imagine that more than a small percentage of consultants will be needed. The top 10% of engineers I think will be just fine for the reasons you've said, but at the lower levels it will be a blood bath (and realistically maybe it should as there are plenty of SWEs that probably shouldn't be writing code that matters, but that feels like a separate discussion). Your point about other skills/knowledge is good too, though I suspect most white collar jobs are on the chopping block too, just maybe shortly behind.
Your future is one that I'm dreaming about too (although I have a hard time believing Apple would allow you to do that, but on Android or some future 3rd option it might be possible). Especially as a Linux user there have been plenty of times I've thought of cool stuff that I'd love to have personally that would take me months of work to build (time I've accepted I'll never have until my kids are all out of the house at least haha). I'm also dreaming of a day when I can just ask the AI to produce more seasons of Star Trek TOS, Have Gun - Will Travel, The Lieutenant, and many other great shows that I'm hungry for more, and have it crank them out. That future would be incredible!
But that feels like the smooth side of the sword, and avoiding a deep cut from the sharp side feels increasingly important. Hopefully it will solve itself but seeing the impacts so far I'm getting worried.
I appreciate the discussion and optimism! There is too much AI doomerism out there and the upsides (like you've mentioned) don't get talked about enough I think.

top_comments.author: thermodynot
top_comments.text:
Computers are not special. They are just a heat engine like everything else. We feed them concentrated energy that they dissipate to do work. They do work on data: we give it data (some of it is called code) and it gives us back data. It's all about the information content, how does that data communicate something and relate to the world?
"Training" is just upfront work. Why on Earth people expect to get from the machine that processes data some novel information that did not exist before?
This whole fantasy hinges on not understand the sheer amount of data these LLMs are being trained on, and some magical thinking about it producing some novel information ex nihilo somehow. I will never understand how intelligent people fall into this patterns of thought.
We can only get from computers what we put into them.

stories.title: YouTube's new anti-adblock measures
stories.author: smitop
stories.article_summary: YouTube is currently A/B testing anti-adblock measures, including a technique called "fake buffering," where the video playback is delayed by 80% of the ad duration, effectively wasting time for users who block ads. This buffering occurs on the initial video request from InnerTube's /youtubei/v1/player endpoint, which is crucial for fetching video data, and is exacerbated by the proprietary SABR (Server ABR) protocol that aims to optimize streaming. A workaround for users is to set the `isInlinePlaybackNoAd` property to true in the JSON requests, which can be implemented using a filter in uBlock Origin. Notably, the filter can be created by hooking into Object.assign instead of JSON.stringify to bypass a newly introduced locker script that prevents modifications to global objects, as detailed by the author who utilized the req2proto tool to extract relevant Protocol Buffers definitions.

agreement_points: There is a consensus that irrelevant advertisements detract from user experience, which is supported by multiple comments emphasizing the aesthetic and contextual issues with billboards.
disagreement_points: A debate exists regarding the nature of advertisements; while some argue that irrelevance is the primary issue, others contend that the visual impact of large billboards is what truly bothers people.

Users express a preference for ad-free experiences, as seen in the positive reception of YouTube Premium, which is viewed as a worthwhile investment for uninterrupted content. The community is divided on the root causes of dissatisfaction with ads, with some attributing it to irrelevance while others focus on the aesthetic impact of large billboards.

top_comments.author: wwweston
top_comments.text:
Paying for YouTube has probably been the digital subscription with the single greatest return on a dozen dollars.
Content is uninterrupted without having to engage in the arms race. Music selection is great. Random movies are available.

top_comments.author: lcnPylGDnU4H9OF
top_comments.text:
The primary thing that makes advertisements disagreeable is their irrelevance. That’s not to say whether or not the advertisement is for a product or service for which the viewer is interested in purchasing but how it relates to the context in which it is viewed.
People complain about billboards next to a countryside highway because it is entirely irrelevant to driving through the countryside. Actual complaints may be about how the billboards block a scenic view but that also seems like another way of complaining about the irrelevance. Similarly, if I am watching a Youtube video, I am never thinking that a disruptive message from a commercial business is relevant to my current activities (uh, passivities?). No advertisement is relevant, not even in-video direct sponsorships, hence SponsorBlock.
If I go to Costco and see an advertisement for tires... well, I’m at Costco, where I buy stuff. Things are sold at Costco and people go there to have things sold to them. I might need tires and realize I can get that taken care of while I’m at Costco. Nearly every advertisement I see at Costco is relevant because it’s selling something I can buy in the same building, indeed usually something juxtaposed close to the advertisement.
I don’t complain about advertisements at Costco because that would be insane. I complain about the advertisements on Youtube because they’re irrelevant and weird but somehow normalized.

top_comments.author: CobrastanJorji
top_comments.text:
> The primary thing that makes advertisements disagreeable is their irrelevance.
That's not true. We don't hate billboards because of their irrelevancy. We hate billboards because they're giant ugly attention grabbers that make the world look worse for everybody in exchange for making someone money. If the billboards were all about driving-related products, they'd still suck.
The YouTube ads are hated because that's the whole point. YouTube has something we want (the video), and they're keeping it from us until they we do something we don't want to do (watch an ad). We dislike these ads almost by definition. If we liked them, we'd seek them out, and we'd call them something else, like "movie trailers" or "Super Bowl ads."

top_comments.author: Defletter
top_comments.text: Steel-manning the argument, near where I live, it's not that uncommon to see small to moderately sized advertisements along the road, such as a sign outside/near the entrance of a farm that's selling eggs, meat, etc. I am wholly unopposed to this. In fact, I'm very supportive of this, and used them to find a farm to buy local honey from. Whereas the stereotypical massive slabs whose advertisements get wallpapered on, I think those are distracting menaces, particularly if the primary way you see them is by driving.

top_comments.author: thejazzman
top_comments.text:
And where I live it's an ever growing hell of political signs, dominos pizza, and anyone else who realizes there is no enforcement against this wide scale littering. The signs are never removed and continue piling up. Abandoned / unmonitored lots are also a frequent target.
And it's rapidly getting worse
Glad you're cool with it though, I guess? Cuz I've considered running for office on the sole platform of having them perpetually removed and perpetrators prosecuted.
There are literally signs advertising to hire people to place more signs.

top_comments.author: jdeibele
top_comments.text:
In Portland, it's against the city code to staple signs to telephone poles.
This is, of course, completely ignored.
There are also signs stuck on wire next to freeway exits or other prime traffic areas. Typically they're on public land because a property owner would want permission or would just remove it.
There are people who angry enough about the sign proliferation that they cut the sign in half so you can't read the phone number or address or whatever.
You should be able to go online and pay a small fee (like $1 or even $.25) per sign that you put up for your garage sale or business. The money could be divided among the city, the pole owner, and people who are paid by the city to remove signs that don't have a QR code or has one that expired.
The fee could be adjusted so that garage sale signs cost much less than business signs. Business signs could only be allowed for businesses who started less than X days ago. Etc.

top_comments.author: ndriscoll
top_comments.text: Where I live, there are sign regulations (total 30 sqft of road signs per lot, or less for smaller lots, 6ft maximum height, minimum 200 ft spacing, up to 2 temporary signs/lot for a maximum 60 days/year, regulations around needing to look nice, etc.). There are signs, but they are much less noticable and more function as a navigation aid rather than a call for attention.

top_comments.author: jonasdegendt
top_comments.text:
Driving through the south is always fun.
> Go to church or the devil will get you!

top_comments.author: dietr1ch
top_comments.text:
On a few nice towns here there's no regular advertisements, but shops are allowed to have nice wooden signs matching the aesthetics of the town signs.
You can still find your way around, and discover things, but looking around feels like you are finding things instead of looking at things yelling at you to find them.

top_comments.author: lcnPylGDnU4H9OF
top_comments.text:
> If the billboards were all about driving-related products, they'd still suck.
To be clear, this is my primary point because I’m driving, not shopping. Something that gets close to maybe agreeable (I would still dislike it) would be an advertisement for a gas/charging station on a long highway. But even then we already have official roadsigns that only show logos and are otherwise relatively unobtrusive. Similar ones for fast food, actually.
Such signs seem agreeable given there is some relevance (I legitimately might be low on gas/battery charge/food satiation levels in a context which I am actually likely to have a specific product need from one or more of the advertised businesses) and they are small enough to be ignorable when they are not actually relevant. The biggest issue I think about with that is how a business gets themselves on the sign but it’s probably not that hard once they are operating next to a highway exit.
(I loathe advertisements, so when I say “agreeable” I mean something like “not wholly disagreeable”.)

stories.title: Harper – an open-source alternative to Grammarly
stories.author: ReadCarlBarks
stories.article_summary: Article content too short to summarize effectively.

agreement_points: There is a consensus that LLMs have overshadowed traditional NLP methods, indicating a significant shift in how language processing is approached and the implications for future developments.
disagreement_points: Some users express skepticism about the effectiveness of Harper's reliance on hard-coded rules compared to LLMs, highlighting a divide in preferences for rule-based versus AI-driven approaches.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion reflects a mix of enthusiasm and skepticism towards language processing tools like Harper and Grammarly. Users appreciate Harper's rule-based approach for its transparency and customization potential, contrasting it with the perceived drawbacks of LLMs, such as verbosity and loss of personal writing style. The community acknowledges the significant evolution from traditional NLP methods to LLMs, indicating a transformative shift in the field.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter expresses enthusiasm for a new writing tool as an alternative to Grammarly but questions its reliance on a limited set of hard-coded rules rather than leveraging decades of natural language processing research and resources. They highlight a potential gap in the tool's approach to language analysis.

tools_mentioned: Harper: An alternative to Grammarly that emphasizes hard-coded grammatical rules, appealing to users who prefer transparency in language processing over the opaque nature of LLMs.

strong_agreements: There is a consensus that LLMs have overshadowed traditional NLP methods, indicating a significant shift in how language processing is approached and the implications for future developments.
major_disagreements: Some users express skepticism about the effectiveness of Harper's reliance on hard-coded rules compared to LLMs, highlighting a divide in preferences for rule-based versus AI-driven approaches.

market_trends: The shift from traditional NLP to LLMs reflects a broader trend in the tech industry, suggesting that companies must adapt to remain competitive in language processing technologies.

working_setups: Users have successfully transitioned from Grammarly to Harper, finding it beneficial for maintaining their writing style while avoiding the verbosity introduced by LLMs.

actionable_advice: Consider trying Harper if you prefer a more rule-based approach to grammar checking, as it allows for customization and avoids the pitfalls of LLMs.
what_to_avoid: Avoid relying solely on LLMs for grammar checking if you value maintaining a personal writing style, as they may lead to overly verbose text.

top_comments.author: oersted
top_comments.text:
Fantastic work, I was so fed up with Grammarly and instantly installed this.
I'm just a bit skeptical about this quote:
> Harper takes advantage of decades of natural language research to analyze exactly how your words come together.
But it's just a rather small collection of hard-coded rules:
https://docs.rs/harper-core/latest/harper_core/linting/trait...
Where did the decades of classical NLP go? No gold-standard resources like WordNet? No statistical methods?
There's nothing wrong with this, the solution is a good pragmatic choice. It's just interesting how our collective consciousness of expansive scientific fields can be so thoroughly purged when a new paradigm arises.
LLMs have completely overshadowed ML NLP methods from 10 years ago, and they themselves replaced decades statistical NLP work, which also replaced another few decades of symbolic grammar-based NLP work.
Progress is good, but it's important not to forget all those hard-earned lessons, it can sometimes be a real superpower to be able to leverage that old toolbox in modern contexts. In many ways, we had much more advanced methods in the 60s for solving this problem than what Harper is doing here by naively reinventing the wheel.

top_comments.author: chilipepperhott
top_comments.text:
I'll admit it's something of a bold label, but there is truth in it.
Before our rule engine has a chance to touch the document, we run several pre-processing steps that imbue semantic meaning to the words it reads.
> LLMs have completely overshadowed ML NLP methods from 10 years ago, and they themselves replaced decades statistical NLP work, which also replaced another few decades of symbolic grammar-based NLP work.
This is a drastic oversimplification. I'll admit that transformer-based approaches are indeed quite prevalent, but I do not believe that "LLMs" in the conventional sense are "replacing" a significant fraction of NLP research.
I appreciate your skepticism and attention to detail.

top_comments.author: tough
top_comments.text: to someone who would like to study/learn that evolution, any good recs?

top_comments.author: aDyslecticCrow
top_comments.text:
Harper is decent.
I've relied on Grammarly to spellcheck all my writing for a few years (dyslexia prevents me from seeing the errors even when reading it 10 times). However, I find its increasing focus on LLMs and its insistence on rewriting sentences in more verbose ways bothers me a lot. (It removes personality and makes human-written text read like AI text.)
So I've tried out alternatives, and Harper is the closest I've found at the moment... but i still feel like grammarly does a better job at the basic word suggestion.
Really, all I wish for is a spellcheck that can use the context of the sentence to suggest words. Most ordinary dictionary spellchecks can pick the wrong word because it's syntactically closer. They may replace "though" with "thought" because I wrote "thougt" when the sentence clearly indicates "though" is correct; and I see no difference visually between any of the three words.

top_comments.author: tolerance
top_comments.text:
I would much rather check my writing against grammatical rules that are hard coded in an open source program—meaning that I can change them—than ones that I imagine would be subject to prompt fiddling or worse; implicitly hard coded in a tangle of training data that the LLM would draw from.
The Neovim configuration for the LSP looks neat: https://writewithharper.com/docs/integrations/neovim
The whole thing seems cool. Automattic should mention this on their homepage. Tools like this are the future of something.

top_comments.author: triknomeister
top_comments.text: You would lose out on evolution of language.

top_comments.author: phoe-krk
top_comments.text: Natural languages evolve so slowly that writing and editing rules for them is easily achievable even this way. Think years versus minutes.

top_comments.author: fakedang
top_comments.text:
Aight you win fam, I was trippin fr. You're absolutely bussin, no cap. Harvard should be taking notes.
(^^ alien language that was developed in less than a decade)

top_comments.author: notahacker
top_comments.text:
The existence of common slang which isn't used in the sort of formal writing that grammar linting tools are typically designed to promote is more of a weakness of learning grammar by a weighted model of the internet vs formal grammatical rules than a strength.
Not an insurmountable problem, ChatGPT will use "aight fam" only in context-sensitive ways and will remove it if you ask to rephrase to sound more like a professor, but RHLFing slang into predictable use is likely a bigger potential challenge than simply ensuring the word list of an open source program is sufficiently up to date to include slang whose etymology dates back to the noughties or nineties, if phrasing things in that particular vernacular is even a target for your grammar linting tool...

top_comments.author: chrisweekly
top_comments.text: Huh, this is the first time I've seen "noughties" used to describe the first decade of the 2000s. Slightly amusing that it's surely pronounced like "naughties". I wonder if it'll catch on and spread.

stories.title: 'Gwada negative': French scientists find new blood type in woman
stories.author: spidersouris
stories.article_summary: A French woman from Guadeloupe has been identified as the only known carrier of a new blood type called "Gwada negative," recognized as the 48th blood group system by France's blood supply agency, EFS. This discovery, which took 15 years to confirm after the initial detection of a "very unusual" antibody in 2011, was made possible through high-throughput DNA sequencing that revealed a genetic mutation. Thierry Peyrard, a medical biologist at EFS, stated, "She is undoubtedly the only known case in the world," highlighting the uniqueness of her blood type inherited from both parents. The EFS noted that this advancement could enhance care for patients with rare blood types, emphasizing the importance of continued research in the field.

agreement_points: The community agrees that monitoring during blood transfusions is crucial to prevent adverse reactions, supported by the standard practice of taking vitals before and during the transfusion.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion highlights the critical importance of understanding blood antigen compatibility in transfusions, particularly the distinction between minor and major antigens. Community members emphasize the necessity of monitoring during transfusions to prevent adverse reactions, supported by standard practices in healthcare. Additionally, real-world examples illustrate the potential consequences of inadequate knowledge in transfusion protocols, underscoring the need for thorough training and adherence to safety guidelines.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter notes that the original post lacks details and references a French article for more information, highlighting that the ISBT has updated its list to include new data, despite the webpage still showing the old number.

specific_numbers: The ISBT has added a new antigen to their list, which is significant because it indicates evolving standards in blood transfusion practices and could impact patient safety and compatibility.

The mention of minor and major antigens is crucial as it highlights the varying levels of risk associated with blood transfusions, where major antigens can lead to life-threatening reactions, thus influencing clinical protocols.

resource_requirements: Close observation for 15 minutes post-transfusion is standard practice, which requires nursing resources. This is essential to monitor for adverse reactions, and failing to do so could result in serious complications for the patient.
Typing blood again before transfusion ensures compatibility, which is critical in preventing transfusion reactions. Not performing this step could lead to severe patient outcomes.

compatibility_issues: The risk of developing sensitivity to minor antigens after multiple transfusions is a concern, particularly in infants. Understanding this can help healthcare providers make informed decisions about transfusion protocols.

strong_agreements: The community agrees that monitoring during blood transfusions is crucial to prevent adverse reactions, supported by the standard practice of taking vitals before and during the transfusion.

failed_attempts: The case of the American high schooler in Uganda illustrates the dangers of inadequate knowledge regarding blood transfusions, showing how lack of awareness can lead to disastrous outcomes.

actionable_advice: Healthcare providers should ensure rigorous crossmatching protocols are followed to minimize the risk of transfusion reactions, which can save lives and improve patient outcomes.
what_to_avoid: Avoid skipping the re-typing of blood before transfusion, as this could lead to severe complications if the blood is not compatible.

top_comments.author: ajb
top_comments.text:
The OP is low on details. There is more in this article (in french): https://www.lindependant.fr/2025/06/21/il-ny-a-quelle-qui-es...
Apparently the ISBT have added this to their list: https://www.isbtweb.org/isbt-working-parties/rcibgt.html (the page still says 47 but the data tables have it added)

top_comments.author: xattt
top_comments.text:
Neither article talks about whether this is a minor or a major antigen.
Blood for transfusion needs to be crossmatched against antigen types of the recipient. Many patients will tolerate several transfusions of a minor mismatched antigen before developing a sensitivity. Major antigens are what cause significant reactions that can be life-threatening.
Minor antigens come into play when crossmatching for infants and premies, but this is way beyond my scope.

top_comments.author: paulgerhardt
top_comments.text:
> Minor antigens come into play when crossmatching for infants
I’m reminded of that American high schooler in Uganda running an orphanage and ran into this exact issue when doing a transfusion on a malnourished infant. [1]
She was skilled enough to perform a transfusion and knowledgeable enough to test for a ABO+/- match but not so knowledgeable as to be sensitive to this issue with disastrous results.
On the other hand her clinics metrics were on par or slightly above the local hospitals so it’s not clear to me they would have faired better getting care elsewhere there.
[1] https://stories.showmax.com/za/hbos-docuseries-savior-comple...

Close observation for 15 minutes is typical for any blood transfusion. You do a set of pre-transfusion vitals, vitals when the blood hits the vein, vitals every 5 minutes until 15 minutes is up, vitals every 15 minutes until the blood is done. Ask any nurse why they hate running blood.
Depending on the severity of the reaction, blood will either be stopped or the patient will be loaded up with Benadryl and Tylenol with the blood running at a slower rate.

stories.title: AbsenceBench: Language models can't tell what's missing
stories.author: JnBrymn
stories.article_summary: The article "AbsenceBench: Language Models Can't Tell What's Missing," authored by Harvey Yiyun Fu and five others, introduces a new benchmark for evaluating large language models (LLMs) on their ability to detect missing information in texts. Despite achieving a 69.6% F1-score on the AbsenceBench tasks with an average context length of 5,000 tokens, even state-of-the-art models like Claude-3.7-Sonnet struggle significantly due to the limitations of Transformer attention mechanisms in recognizing "gaps" in documents. The benchmark tests LLMs across three domains: numerical sequences, poetry, and GitHub pull requests, highlighting a critical distinction between tasks where models excel (e.g., Needle in a Haystack) and those where they falter. The research underscores the need for improved model architectures to better handle information omissions.

agreement_points: There is a consensus on the ongoing relevance of data augmentation techniques like rotation and flipping, as they are essential for enhancing model training and performance, supported by historical practices in deep learning.
disagreement_points: Some community members debate the effectiveness of certain augmentation techniques, such as rotation, arguing that they may not always align with the model's learning objectives, indicating a need for careful consideration of augmentation strategies.
comments_analysis.sentiment_summary: The discussion emphasizes the importance of data augmentation techniques in machine learning, with community members reflecting on historical practices and their relevance today. The consensus is that methods like image rotation and flipping remain critical for enhancing model performance, though there are debates about their effectiveness in certain contexts. Experts highlight the significance of understanding data characteristics, particularly in specialized fields like radar signal analysis, to ensure accurate model training.
comments_analysis.top_comment_summary: The commenter highlights the limitations of AI image recognition by sharing their experience with Claude, which successfully identified a Kanizsa triangle in one orientation but failed to recognize it when rotated, demonstrating challenges in understanding abstract visual cues.

specific_numbers: The mention of rotating images in training data highlights the importance of data augmentation techniques in machine learning, which can significantly improve model performance by providing diverse training samples.
tools_mentioned: Claude is discussed as an AI model capable of image recognition and summarization, indicating its potential applications in understanding visual data, which is crucial for tasks requiring visual comprehension.
performance_data: The reference to AlexNet's use of horizontal flipping as a data augmentation method illustrates how foundational techniques in deep learning can influence current practices, emphasizing the need for models to generalize well across varied inputs.

resource_requirements: The discussion on look angle/platform angle in radar applications suggests that understanding specific signal characteristics is crucial for effective data collection, indicating that neglecting these factors could lead to suboptimal results.
efficiency_gains: Data augmentation is noted as a method to increase sample size without additional data collection costs, which can lead to improved model accuracy and robustness in real-world applications.

strong_agreements: There is a consensus on the ongoing relevance of data augmentation techniques like rotation and flipping, as they are essential for enhancing model training and performance, supported by historical practices in deep learning.
major_disagreements: Some community members debate the effectiveness of certain augmentation techniques, such as rotation, arguing that they may not always align with the model's learning objectives, indicating a need for careful consideration of augmentation strategies.

top_comments.author: birdfood
top_comments.text:
Perhaps related, after watching a talk by Gerald Sussman I loaded an image of the Kanizsa triangle into Claude and asked it a pretty vague question to see if it could “see” the inferred triangle. It recognised the image and went straight into giving me a summary about it. So I rotated the image 90 degrees and tried in a new conversation, it didn’t recognise the image and got the number of elements incorrect:
This image shows a minimalist, abstract geometric composition with several elements:
Four black shapes that appear to be partial circles or "Pac-Man" like forms, each with a wedge cut out, positioned in the four corners/quadrants of the image Two thin black triangular or arrow-like shapes - one pointing upward in the upper left area, and one pointing to the right in the center-right area All elements are arranged on a light gray or off-white background

top_comments.author: latentsea
top_comments.text: I guess they will now just rotate all the images in the training data 90 degrees too to fill this kind of gap.

top_comments.author: recursivecaveat
top_comments.text: Everything old is new again: in the Alexnet paper that kicked off the deep learning wave in 2012, they describe horizontally flipping every image as a cheap form of data augmentation. Though now that we expect models to actually read text that seems potentially counter-productive. Rotations are similar, in that you'd hope it would learn heuristics such as that the sky is almost always at the top.

top_comments.author: bonoboTP
top_comments.text: That's called data augmentation. It was common alredy before AlexNet. And it never stopped being common, it's still commonly done.

top_comments.author: latency-guy2
top_comments.text: At least from when I was still doing this kind of work, look angle/platform angle scatterer signal (radar) mattered more than rotation, but rotation was a simple way to get quite a bit more samples. It never stopped being relevant :)

top_comments.author: mirekrusin
top_comments.text:
That's how you train neural network with synthetic data so it extracts actual meaning.
That's how humans also learn ie. adding numbers. First there is naive memoization, followed by more examples until you get it.
LLM training seems to be falling into memoization trap because models are extremely good at it, orders of magnitude better than humans.
IMHO what is missing in training process is this feedback explaining wrong answer. What we're currently doing with training is leaving out this understanding as "exercise to the reader". We're feeding correct answers to specific, individual examples which promotes memoization.
What we should be doing in post training is ditch direct backpropagation on next token, instead let the model finish its wrong answer, append explanation why it's wrong and continue backpropagation for final answer - now with explanation in context to guide it to the right place in understanding.
What all of this means is that current models are largely underutilized and unnecessarily bloated, they contain way too much memoized information. Making model larger is easy, quick illusion of improvement. Models need to be squeezed more, more focus needs to go towards training flow itself.

top_comments.author: atwrk
top_comments.text:
> That's how humans also learn ie. adding numbers. First there is naive memoization, followed by more examples until you get it.
Just nitpicking here, but this isn't how humans learn numbers. They start at birth with competency up to about 3 or 5 and expand from that. So they can already work with quantities of varying size (i.e. they know which is more, the 4 apples on the left or the five on the right, and they also know what happens if I take one apple from the left and put it to the others on the right), and then they learn the numbers. So yes, they learn the numbers through memorization, but only the signs/symbols, not the numeric competency itself.

top_comments.author: mirekrusin
top_comments.text:
Turtles all the way down, things like meaning of "more" is also memoized ie initially as "I want more food" etc. then refined with time, ie. kid saying "he's more than me" is corrected by explaining that there needs to be some qualifier for measurable quantity ie. "he's more tall (taller) than me" or "he is more fast (faster) than me" etc.
Using different modalities (like images, videos, voice/sounds instead of pure text) is interesting as well as it helps completing the meaning, adds sense of time etc.
I don't think we're born with any concepts at all, it's all quite chaotic initially with consistent sensory inputs that we use to train/stabilise our neural network. Newborns for example don't even have concept of separation between "me and the environment around me", it's learned.

top_comments.author: littlestymaar
top_comments.text:
And it will work.
I just whish the people believing LLM can actually reason and generalize see that they don't.

top_comments.author: ben_w
top_comments.text:
If that was evidence current AI don't reason, then the Thatcher effect would be evidence that humans don't: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thatcher_effect
LLMs may or may not "reason", for certain definitions of the word (there are many), but this specific thing doesn't differentiate them from us.
